newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-C&W to buy BellSouth Optus stake.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-C&W to buy BellSouth Optus stake.

text.p: Britain's Cable & Wireless Plc will acquire BellSouth Corp Inc's 24.5 percent stake in Australian telecommunication group Optus Communications Pty Ltd, taking its stake to 49 percent, Optus said on Tuesday.
C&W will acquire BellSouth's 490 million shares in Optus for A$980 million, plus an interest in a cellular property in Latin America, Optus said.
In addition, C&W will receive from Optus the right to buy a further 289.9 million ordinary shares at A$1.75 a share exercisable over the next three years, Optus's acting chairman Bob Dalziel said.
"Mayne Nickless Ltd and the Australian institutional investors retain their respective holdings of 25 percent and 26 percent," he said in a statement.
"Should Cable & Wireless exercise all its options, its stake in Optus would increase beyond 50 percent," he said.
The initial transaction is subject to Australian government and Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) approval, he said.

"This new shareholding structure creates a focus and clear commitment to Optus's integrated communications strategy, which draws on the combined strength of broadband, wireline, wireless and satellite technologies," Dalziel said.
Dalziel, who is managing director of Mayne Nickless, said he was speaking on behalf of the shareholders.
Optus's recently appointed chief executive officer, Peter Howell-Davies, will hold a media conference at 0100 GMT (11 a.m.) in Sydney on Wednesday to outline his plans for the group, Optus added.
He had been CEO of a C&W unit.
In a separate statement, Dalziel said as Mayne Nickless's managing director that Mayne Nickless welcomed the agreement.
He noted that the the C&W call options are only exercisable if the mooted float of Optus proceeds.

Under the agreement, Mayne Nickless will no longer be required to underwrite the A$100 million incentive offered by Optus to the US West Inc group to assist in the rollout of local telephony services, he said in a statement.
As part of the same arrangement, Mayne Nickless will also not take up an additional 30 million shares at A$1 each in Optus, he said.
These arrangements were part of the March settlement which allowed Optus to take full ownership of the Optus Vision pay television group, Dalziel said.
The US West incentive payments will continue to be borne by Optus.

"Optus is looking forward to actively participating in the rationalisation of the Australian pay TV industry and associated cable infrastructure issues which will pave the way for a float of Optus as soon as possible," Dalziel said.
